channel.title: First source mod
channel.description:
I like the idea of starting to mod the source engine and eventually make a full mod but I don't know where to start. I've looked around for tutorials but they all seem to be for specific thing and I feel rather overwhelmed.
I'm sure there are people here with talent and experience and so I was wondering if anyone could give me an idea where to start and what programs are used and where is the best place to start or had any tips for a (not even yet) newbie to (the modding side of) source.
Sorry if this has posted before but I tried the search but looking for something like 'source mod' didn't have any useful results.

item.title: First source mod
item.dc:creator: Spycrabz
item.description:
geekofalltrades:

I am shocked an appalled that no one has linked him to the Valve Developer Community Wiki. That’s where I learned to mod; basically, I decided one day that I wanted to start modding, and I went to the wiki and, for several months, did nothing but read the articles. Then when I started up hammer, I already had a good understanding of how everything works.

I never direct newbies to the Dev Wiki, it can be a bit daunting unless you know what you’re looking for.

Read full topic

item.title: First source mod
item.dc:creator: horizonbreakk
item.description:
ok. i may be a lil late but here https://developer.valvesoftware.com/wiki/SketchUp_Source_Tools

its basically a plugin guide thingy on how to make models and maps using sketchup. which is a fairly easy, though not nearly as powerful as blender… maybe you could use it to hash out quick maps or models?

Read full topic

item.description:

item.title: First source mod
item.dc:creator: Shaktal
item.description:
Blender has some functions which are not readily available in Commercial packages. Because it is open-source, they can put in functions that haven’t been fully stabalised, because they have nothing to use.

But for immediate ease of use, and render quality etc. use 3DS Max, that comes with excellent functions, It is easy to use at first, and although the learning curve gets steeper the move you delve into the program, it is a great choice of 3D Modelling program.

But basically, you need to try a multitude of different Modelling programs, and make your own decision based on that.

EDIT: The main 3D Programs (As far as I’m aware) are:

  • 3DS Max
  • Blender
  • Maya
  • XSI

Try those if you can, and then chose your favourite one out of them. And don’t always go by what other people say, a lot of people seem to heavily bias in favour of the modelling program they use.

Read full topic

item.title: First source mod
item.dc:creator: Jingles
item.description:

item.title: First source mod
item.dc:creator: JeffMOD
item.description:
TWHL is a good place for mapping tutorials for the basics, and the userbase will most likely be able to help with any question you have, regardless of which stream you’re working in.

Of course, mapping is where all the other streams come together- without maps, all a mod is is new code and models, with nowhere to show them off.

If you’re going to mod for source, you need the SDK and the SDK Base for whatever engine subversion you want to mod. Open the SDK, select “create a mod” and follow the instructions. Your mod will be fully set up shortly! (Of course, it will be a copy of the Lostcoast source test, so you’ll want to do actual work before you ship it.)

Read full topic

edit: I’ve been thinking that I could start learning mapping or making skins or models, thanks for the links for the mapping I’ll look at those now.
